Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2010 07:48AM dswope wrote: I not only have tears, I'm full on crying!  (and at work!)  Sometimes I feel so alone in this journey, it feels so good to realize again there are people out there writing songs, raising money, volunteering, etc. all for this cause.  What a wonderful son you have raised kim40.  How proud you must be.
Posts.Title: My Son made me cry yesterday kim40 Rhonda1966

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2009 10:22AM dswope wrote: Again, great information!  I personally don't pay enough attention to what the nurses are doing.....never even considered that they might be leaving the tourniquet on too long.  After I read your post I remembered that last week she left it on long enough that it became very uncomfortable.  It's good to know we have options.  I'm one of those people that just goes in, tries to not be any trouble, and trusts that they will always do the right thing.  I'll pay more attention!  Linda - you are awesome with knowledge...please don't stop! Thank you, thank you.
Posts.Title: I feel stupid for even asking this lovinmomma LindaLou53

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2009 11:33AM dswope wrote: Linda, Wow!  Thanks. Love your wind, and love the knowledge shared on these boards.  I guess my fear stems from the nurses questioning the fact that I have no port.  I did have a total mastectomy, 4 nodes from 1 side& and 5 from the other.  I would certainly prefer to continue using my veins, but scared to have something else go wrong through this proceedure.  I'll speak to my ONC about it.
Posts.Title: I feel stupid for even asking this lovinmomma LindaLou53

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2009 05:22PM dswope wrote: May I ask if any of you have any idea why my ONC has never even mentioned the possibility of a port?  I'm doing CMF.  However, they draw blood and give me the MF portion once a week for 12 weeks.  Should I be insisting on using veins in my legs?  Actually, one of the nurses asked me where my port was.  Just when you think you know what you're doing.....
Posts.Title: I feel stupid for even asking this lovinmomma LindaLou53

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2009 12:41PM dswope wrote: Linda, Also last week, when I went to have my blood drawn I asked if they could go ahead and insert the IV so I wouldn't have to be poked twice (needles not knowledge!).  They had done that for me the week before.  The tech came back and told me the onc nurses were to busy.  Should I have insisted or should I ask my onc to request it...can she?  I'm going to call my onc's nurse today...she's a peach, but has nothing to do with the blood draw or the chemo.  I'm sure she'll let me know what the proceedures are at my hosp.  I understand they are busy...I was amazed, the first time I went, to see all the women waiting for various cancer proceedures.  What a depressing sight. Thanks again. Deb
Posts.Title: I feel stupid for even asking this lovinmomma LindaLou53

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2009 10:21AM dswope wrote: Good Morning All, I was wondering, from those of you that have completed the chemo, what happens next?  My doc is being kind of vague.  What tests do they perform to determine whether or not the cancer has come back?  How often do they perform these tests?  I will go on some kind of aromatase inhibitor, to be determined.  My onc says she won't really need to see me unless I am having pains in certain areas.....I'm so confused again!  Maybe she is just waiting until this last round is over to focus on the next step.  Anyway, any advice or experience would be helpful.  Thanks.
